docs.lead_paragraph: MYTHS about vitamin E have flourished since its birth as an essential nutrient in 1922, with the discovery that rats could not reproduce without it. Within a decade after the discovery by Dr. H. M. Evans and Dr. K. S. Bishop, vitamin E acquired a mystique as an enhancer and restorer of sexual and reproductive function, an image reflected in its chemical name, tocopherol, from the Greek for "to bring forth in childbirth" or, more colloquially, "oil of fertility."
